Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative CDI-Type II: Cyber Enabled Discovery System for Advanced Multidisciplinary Study of Humanitarian Logistics for Disaster Response

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will develop a cyber-enabled discovery system, integrating state of the art thinking and methodologies from computer, transportation, mathematical, and social sciences, for management of logistics in humanitarian responses to disasters. It will (1) create new paradigms of humanitarian logistic models that explicitly consider two key aspects not studied by the current techniques: non-hysteretic deprivation costs (lack of access to a given good or service), and materiel convergence (physical movement of supplies and equipment); (2) develop appropriate models to represent human suffering as a deprivation cost; (3) develop analytical models to quantify and influence the amount, type, and arrival patterns of donations; (4) gain insight into the links between media framing of needs and materiel convergence; (5) define mechanisms to modify donor behavior; and, (6) develop algorithms and heuristics to solve these formulations. This will lead to models that correctly consider the impacts of logistic decisions on the impacted populations, more effective delivery strategies, more coordinated and effective relief flows, and less congestion at entry points.

This research is an ambitious and transformative effort to build a holistic, quantitative understanding of how humanitarian logistics should consider deprivation costs and emergent donor response to disasters. This is based on state of the art economic, logistic, and social science research into the impacts of delivery actions, media portrayal of disaster events, and response needs. The core impact of this research will be improved allocation and delivery of critical supplies during disaster response, as well as better coordination with emergent distributed donor sites, leading to improvement of the nation?s emergency response capabilities. The research team will maximize the broader impacts through: (1) the integration of research into undergraduate and graduate courses; (2) the involvement of undergraduate and graduate students as research assistants; (3) the use of outreach events to communicate research results to undergraduate and high school students and stimulate them into research; (4) the recruitment of women and minority students; and (5) the dissemination of project findings among professionals and researchers with interest in humanitarian logistics and disaster response.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results from this project have significantly improved the formulations of humanitarian logistic models by incorporating welfare economic principles in these models, ensuring that resulting strategies lead to the greatest good for the greatest number of people. The analyses conducted propose the use of social costs—the summation of logistic and deprivation costs—as the preferred objective function for post-disaster humanitarian logistic models. By defining deprivation cost as the economic valuation of human suffering associated with a lack of access to a good or service, it is possible to account for the impacts of the distribution strategy. A review of the philosophy and economics literature was conducted to identify proper foundations for their estimation.

This new modeling paradigm has allowed the development of several mathematical models for humanitarian logistics applications. Such models include the incorporation of social costs into inventory-allocation distribution models to maximize the benefits derived from the distribution of critical supplies to populations in need after a disaster. Another application addressed the challenge of districting the disaster area so that the groups responding to the disaster do not overlap and duplicate efforts. This research proposes two mathematical formulations that optimally subdivide the impacted area among relief groups taking into account the amount of resources brought to the area, as well as capacities of candidate sites and the population needs, with the objective of minimizing the social costs of the strategy. Moreover, the project supported research that proposed a mathematical model to solve the problem of access restoration after disasters. This model takes into account capacity and scheduling constraints to optimally allocate resources during the response stage, while minimizing social costs. A heuristic procedure was developed to solve large instances in short execution times, including applications for search-and-rescue activities in post-disaster contexts.

Besides proposing the concept of Deprivation Costs, the project provided the support to estimate Deprivation Cost Functions (DCF), obtaining a DCF for drinkable water using Contingent Valuation. The results indicate that deprivation costs for drinkable water have a non-linear relation with deprivation times. A parallel study investigated the use of economic valuation techniques to gain insight into anticipation effects—those related to anxiety and deprivation of a critical supply—in post-disaster environments. The estimated DCFs provide a consistent metric that could be incorporated into humanitarian logistic mathematical models, eliminating the need to use proxy metrics, and providing a better way to assess the impacts of delivery options and actions.

In a post-disaster environment, uncertainty often impacts all aspects of the relief efforts, the research developed formulation to choose a set of distribution centers to open from a list of available facilities and to assign every member of the population to a distribution center. The inclusion of a term inspired by conditional value-at-risk, or CVaR, helps to further minimize potential disparities. Moreover, in many humanitarian logistics optimization problems, some of the variables are subject to a convex nonlinear constraint, with the parameters of that constraint determined through the solution of a nonlinear regression model. A framework was developed for applying robust optimization to problems of this form, by constructing a piecewise linear approximation to the convex constraint.

Findings from analysis on interviews conducted after Hurricane Sandy and the 2013 Oklahoma tornadoes reveal that individuals involved in the supply chain differentially assign value in the donations process. Overall, alignment of donor interests and survivor interests was constructed as necessary, however donation drive coordinators lacked a clear understanding of how to align the interests of survivors and donors.  Finally, findings from this study have significantly changed our thinking of disaster donations. Although the influx of unnecessary goods has long flowed to disaster impacted areas alongside necessary items, this research has demonstrated the motivations behind such giving. Rather than addressing specific survivor needs, the study has illustrated the various objectives donation efforts serve aside from meeting survivor needs. As part the project, the team collected survey data and analyzed factors that influence types of donation selected and the best ways to induce change in donation choice. The research shows that donors perceive impacted populations as isolated and unable to purchase goods from the local markets, hence the need for physical items to be transported to their aid.

The outcomes and research findings from this project are frequently integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses on disaster science, engineering and management and forms part of the curriculum for a teaching institute for public school teachers. Wide dissemination of results has occurred, including presentations to public officials, private sector representatives, non-governmental organizations, and local community groups. Investigators are routinely asked by journalists to share project insights with the public following major disaster events.  The project has involved the participation of undergraduate and graduate students, including women and historically underrepresented groups. Graduating students have taken tenure-track academic appointments at different institutions.
